question: CASE:  A 6-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric clinic. He had a cough of 10 days duration. His illness started with cold-like symptoms followed by worsening cough and in the last 3 days he was getting frequent paroxysms of cough occasionally followed by vomiting. He had not received any antibiotic for the infection. Immunization history showed that the boy had not received the 2 booster doses of DTaP scheduled at 18 months and at 4-6 years. Based on the nature of cough and the history of immunization, the clinician considered whooping cough as a possibility. Clinical samples were collected for laboratory investigations before the child was placed on antibiotic. Which of the following will be the most suitable clinical specimen for cultural isolation of the causative agent of whooping cough?

CASE:   A sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from a 12-month-old baby girl, clinically diagnosed as having pyogenic meningitis, was received in a microbiology laboratory.Gram-stain of the CSF showed numerous polymorphs and small gram-negative pleomorphic bacilli with coccoid and filamentous forms. CSF was cultured on sheep blood agar and chocolate agar with a strain of staphylococcus streaked across the medium. The plates were incubated at 37°C, in presence of 5% carbon dioxide After 24 hours of incubation, small opaque colonies appeared on the media. The colonies were larger and more developed near the staphylococcal growth than those away from it. The bacterium was oxidase, catalase positive, and produced beta-lactamase. It was non-motile and failed to grow on MacConkey's medium. The isolate was identified and the serotype was determined using specific antisera. It was one of the important agents of bacterial meningitis in children. A vaccine is now widely used in developed countries for the prevention of this bacterial infection and has helped to reduce the disease incidence considerably.
